Award.AwardTitle: NUE ASCCEND: Addressing Social Challenges through Creativity, Engineering, Nanotechnology, and Diversity

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program entitled, "NUE ASCCEND: Addressing Social Challenges through Creativity, Engineering, Nanotechnology, and Diversity", at the University of Connecticut under the direction of Dr. Leslie M. Shor, will create an interdisciplinary undergraduate engineering concentration in creativity and technical innovation that is focused on the societal impacts of nanotechnology.

The structure of the concentration will be an interdisciplinary three-course sequence open to all engineers that will be taught collaboratively by project staff from 5 university programs. These courses are "Nanoscience and Society", "Managing Creativity and Innovation", and "Interdisciplinary Senior Design: Nanotechnology". Together the departments of the project staff represent ~45% of all UConn engineering students including 75% of female students. ASCCEND will elevate engineering education at UConn and beyond by placing technology and innovation in a direct social context. Furthermore, by providing students with specific training in managing creativity and evaluating technology in interdisciplinary settings, ASCCEND participants will be more agile and productive members of the evolving global workplace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop an innovative sequence of courses to train engineers to evaluate socially-responsible nanotechnology solutions that meet specific societal challenges, and through this educational development, diversify the engineering student population. Activities centered in three main areas: course development, outreach, and basic research into the factors that motivate under-represented minorities to study engineering.

Three new courses were developed and taught multiple times at the University of Connecticut. The first course, “Nanoscience and Society,” trains students to evaluate social impacts of existing technologies through case studies, guest lectures, and group work. The second course, “Managing Creativity and Innovation” is a hybrid engineering and management course where student groups are trained to enhance their own creativity and to better manage the creative process within diverse groups. The course has been recognized by the UConn School of Business with an innovation in education award, and it is a model for inter-school collaboration and partnership. The third course, “Capstone Design Marketplace” lets students from across engineering apply their individual and disciplinary technical skills to contribute solutions to a design challenge posed by a peer from a different engineering field. This course makes extensive use of peer evaluation supported through well-defined deliverables and detailed evaluation rubrics to help make the course scalable with large enrollments.

An important cross-cutting theme of the project is creativity. Through a faculty seminar series on creativity and a workshop on creativity in instruction, we have made linkages across fields and helped faculty implement creativity research in the classroom through practical instruction strategies.   

Through this project, we also sought to understand the persistent lack of diversity in engineering. We surveyed 806 students, primarily freshmen, with approximately 50 percent of participants women and 36 percent engineering majors. Guided by Social Cognitive Career Theory, our survey instrument examined a broad list of factors from personal characteristics and abilities and confidence level, to abilities and professional orientation of parents and friends and the potential influence of these social groups on the choice of a major.  Our findings demonstrate that confidence in abilities and intrinsic interest in major and potential to make a difference were significant factors for individuals to choose a major. But surprisingly, these factors were not different among major or gender, and therefore unlikely to explain the gender gap. Interestingly, parents and friends played a significant role in the selection of engineering as a major, but for women only.

Our vocational research results suggest women still need more support and acceptance than men to choose engineering as a career, and that they need this in addition to their own intrinsic interest in the field. The conventional wisdom has been that we need to do a better job reaching out to young women to convince them to enter technical fields. It may be that better outreach to parents and teachers is what is needed next. Ultimately, once the full breadth of society is reflected in the field of engineering, society may expect to receive better, more creative solutions for a broader range of problems.
